patient_information: A 34-year-old Malawian woman, HIV-positive with a baseline CD4 count of 54/μL. Diagnosed with smear-positive pulmonary tuberculosis 5 months prior. Works as a street vendor selling mobile phone vouchers. Divorced, no children. Lives in an urban high-density area.
chief_complaint: Slowly progressive weakness of the left arm and leg.
history_of_present_illness: Problems started approximately 3 months earlier with a limp in her left leg. Weakness progressed over following weeks to also affect her left arm. Onset was insidious and slowly progressive. Denies head trauma, headache, recent fever, nausea, visual impairment, or weight loss. Review of systems unremarkable. Diagnosed with smear-positive pulmonary tuberculosis 5 months prior. HIV-reactive with baseline CD4 count of 54/μL at that time. Started on antituberculous therapy, vitamin B6, antiretroviral therapy, and co-trimoxazole prophylaxis, all of which she is currently taking.
exposure_and_epidemiology: From Malawi, lives in an urban high-density area. Works as a street vendor. HIV-positive and previously diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis.
physical_exam: General examination normal apart from slightly pale conjunctivae. Fundoscopy shows normal fundi without papilloedema or retinitis. Neurological examination reveals spastic hemiparesis on the left with hyperreflexia. Power in left leg 2/5 (active movement with gravity eliminated) and left arm 3/5 (active movement against gravity). Pronator drift on the left indicating proximal weakness. Sensation of pain reduced in left leg and hand. Cranial nerves examination normal.
labs_and_diagnostics: Baseline CD4 count: 54/μL. Full blood count: WBC 3.8 x 10^9/L (reference range: 4–10), haemoglobin 9.9 g/dL (12–14), platelets 140 x 10^9/L (150–350). Routine CSF examination was normal. India Ink stain and fungal cultures were negative. Patient was put on a waiting list for a cerebral MRI scan.
differential_diagnosis: Focal brain lesion(s) in HIV-infected individuals, including: HIV-related brain diseases (cerebral toxoplasmosis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, CNS lymphoma, cryptococcoma, CMV encephalitis). Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection of the brain (tuberculoma or tuberculous abscess). Brain tumour, brain metastases, cerebral abscess. Endemic 'tropical' diseases (neurocysticercosis, neuroschistosomiasis, Chagas’ disease). Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS), specifically unmasking or paradoxical IRIS, possibly involving tuberculoma, PML, cryptococcoma, or toxoplasmosis. CNS tuberculosis deterioration post-ART/TB treatment.
management_and_clinical_course: Ongoing antituberculous therapy, vitamin B6, antiretroviral therapy, and co-trimoxazole prophylaxis. Started on empirical antitoxoplasmosis treatment with high-dose co-trimoxazole. ART and antituberculous treatment were continued. Prednisolone 1mg/kg bodyweight was added for presumed IRIS. Put on a waiting list for a cerebral MRI scan. At 4-week follow-up, clinical status was unchanged. At 8 weeks, there was further deterioration of power in her left hand.
final_diagnosis: Not mentioned (text ends before final diagnosis). Presumed IRIS is being treated empirically.
disease_name_short: HIV-associated neurological disorder with focal brain lesion
